availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.author: Marvell, Andrew, 1621-1678.
Dryden, John, 1631-1700.
Sprat, Thomas, 1635-1713.
Waller, Edmund, 1606-1687.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in the University of Illinois (Urbana-Champaign Campus). Library.

Advice to a painter -- Hodge's vision -- Britain and Raleigh -- Statue at Stocks-M. -- Young statesman -- To the K- -- Nostradamus prophecy -- Sir Edmondbery Godfrey's ghost -- On the King's voyage to Chattam -- Poems on Oliver / by Mr. Dryden, Mr. Sprat, and Mr. Waller.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
A COLLECTION OF POEMS ON Affairs of State; Viz.
Advice to a Painter.
Hodge's Viion.
Britain and Raleigh.
Statue at Stocks—M—
Young Stateman.
To the K—
Notradamus Prophecy.
Sir Edmundbury Godfrey's Ghot.
On the King's Voyage to Chattam.
Poems on Oliver, by Mr. Dryden, Mr. Sprat, and Mr. Waller.
By A—M—l Eq and other Eminent Wits.
LONDON, Printed in the Year, MDCLXXXIX.

div.head: Advice to a Painter, by A. M. Eq

lg.l: Spread a large Canvas, Painter, to contain
The great Aembly, and the num'rous Train,
Where all about him hall in Triumph it
Abhorring Widom and depiing Wit,
Hating all Jutice and reolv'd to Fight.
Firt draw His Highnes protrate to the South,
Adoring Rome, with this Speech in his Mouth.
Mot Holy Father, being joyn'd in League
With Father P—s, D—y, and with Teague,
Thrown at your Sacred Feet, I humbly bow,
I and the wie Aociates of my Vow;
A Vow, nor Fire nor Sword hall ever end,
Till all this Nation to your Foottool bend:
Thus arm'd with Zeal and Bleings from your Hands,
I'le raie my Papits, and my Irih Bands;
And by a Noble well-contrived Plot,
Manag'd by wie Fitz—and by Scot,
Prove to the World, I'le have Old England know,
That common Sene is my Eternal Foe.
I ne'r can fight in a more glorious Caue,
Than to detroy their Liberty and Laws,
Their Houe of Commons, and their Houe of Lords,
Parliaments, Precedents and dull Records;
Shall thee e'r dare to contradict my Will,
And think a Prince oth' Blood can e'r do Ill?
It is our Birth-right to have Power to kill.
Shall they e're dare to think they hall decide
The Way to Heaven, and who hall be my Guide?
Shall they pretend to ay, That Bread is Bread,
Or there's no Purgatory for the Dead?
That Extream Unction is but common Oyl,
And not Infallibly the Roman Spoil?
I will have Villains in our Notions ret,
And I do ay it, therefore it's the bet.
Next Painter draw his M—by his ide,
Conveying his Religion and his Bride;
He who long ince abjur'd the Royal Line,
Does now in Popery with his Mater joyn.
Then draw the Princes with her golden Locks,
Hatning to be envenom'd with the P—
And in her youthful Veins receive a Wound,
Which ent N. H. before her, under Ground;
The Wound of which the tainted Ch—fades,
Laid up in Store for a new Set of Maids.
Poor Princes, born under a ullen Star,
To find uch Welcome when you came o far!
Better ome jealous Neighbour of your own
Had call'd you to a Sound, tho' petty Throne,
Where 'twixt a wholeom Husband and a Page,
You might have linger'd out a lazy Age,
Than on dull Hopes of being here a Q—
E're twenty dye, and rot before fifteen.
Now Painter hew us in the Blacket Dye,
The Counellors of all this Villany:
Cl—d, who firt appear'd in humble guie,
Was always thought too Gentle, Meek and Wie:
But when he came to act upon the Stage,
He prov'd the mad Cethegus of our Age;
He and his D—ke had both too great a Mind,
To be by Jutice or by Law confin'd;
Their boyling Heads can hear no other Sounds
Than Fleets and Armies, Battails, Blood and Woun'ds;
And to detroy our Liberty they hope,
By Irih Talbot, and old doting Pope.
Next Talbot mut by his great Mater tand,
Laden with Folly, Fleh, and Ill-got Land;
He's of a ize indeed to fill a Porch,
But ne're can make a Pillar of the Church;
His Sword is all his Argument, not his Book,
Alt ho no Scholar, he can act the Cook;
And will cut Throats again, if he be paid;
In th' Irih Shambles he firt learn'd the Trade.
Then Painter hew thy Skill, and in fit place,
Let's ee the Nuncio A—ll's weet Face.
Let the Beholders by thy Art epy
His Sene and Soul, as quinting as his Eye.
Let B—s autumnal Face be een,
Rich with the Spoils of a poor Algerine,
Who truting in him, was by him betray'd;
And o hall we when his Advice's obey'd:
Great Heroes to get Honour by the Sword,
He got his Wealth by breaking of his Word;
And now his Daughter he hath got with Child,
And Pimps to have his Family defil'd,
Next Painter draw the Rabble of the Plot,

l.hi: G—n, Fitz G—d, Loftus, Porter, Scot:

lg.l: Thee are fit Heads indeed, to turn a State,
And change the Order of a Nations Fate;
Ten thouand uch as thee hall ne'r controul
The mallet Atom of an Englih Soul.
Old England on a trong Foundation tands,
Defying all their Heads and all their Hands,
Its teady Bais never could be hook,
When Wier Men her Ruin undertook:
And can her Guardian Angels let her toop
At lat, to Madmen, Fools, and to the Pope?
No Painter, no cloe up this Piece and See,
This crowd of Traitors hang'd in EFFIGIE.

div.head: Hodge, a Countryman, went up to the Piramid, His VISION.

lg.l: WHen Hodge had numbred up, how many Score
The airy Piramid contain'd, he wore,
No mortal Wight e'r climb'd o high before.
To th' bet Advantage plac'd, he Views around,
Th' Imperial Throne with lofty Turrets crown'd,
The wealthy Store-houe of the bounteous Flood,
Whoe paceful Tide o're-flows our Land with Good:
Confued Forms fleet by his wondring Eyes,
And his Soul too, eiz'd by Divine urprize.
Some God it eems had entred his plain Breat,
And with's Abode that Rutick Manion blet.
A mighty Change he feels in ev'ry part;
Light guides his Eyes, and Widom rules his Heart:
So when her pious Son, fair Venus how'd
His flaming Troy, with laughter'd Dardan's Strow'd,
She purg'd his Optick Films, his clouded Sight,
Then Troy's lat Doom he read by Heaven's Light;
Such Light Divine did eize the dazling Eyes
Of humble Hodge.
Regions remote, Courts, Councils, Policies
The Circling Wills of Tyrants Treacheries
He views, dicerns, deciphers, penetrates,
From Charle's Dukes, to Europe's armed States.
He aw the Goatih King in his Alcove,
With ecret Scenes of his incetuous Love;
To whom he poke:
Ceae, ceae, O Charles, thus to pollute our Ile;
Return, return to thy long wiht Exile;
There with thy Court deile the neighb'ring States.
And by thy Crimes participate their Fates.
He aw the Duke in his curt Divan et
To's vat Deigns reaching his Pigmy-Wit,
With a choice Knot of the Ignatian Crew,
Who th' way to Murthers and to Treaons hew:
Dienters they oppres with Laws evere
That whilt we wound thee innocents, we fear
Their cured Seed we may be forc'd to pare.
Twice the Reform'd mut fight a double Prize,
That Rome and France may in their Ruines rie.
Old Bonner ingle Hereticks did burn,
Thee Reform'd Cities into Ahes turn,
And ev'ry year new Fires make us mourn.
Hybernian Tories plot his cruel Reign,
And thirt for Englih Martyrs Blood again.
Our Valiant Youth abroad mut learn the Trade
Of unjut War, their Countrey to invade;
Others at home mut grind us to prepare
Our Gallick Necks their Iron Yoke to wear.
Ships, once our Safety and our glorious Might,
Are doom'd with Worms and Rottennes to fight;
Whilt France rides Sovereign o're the Britih Main,
Our Merchants robb'd, and brave Sea-men lain:
T' inure his Plot, France mut his Legions end,
Rome to retore, and to enthrone his Friend:
Thus the rah Phaeton with Fury hurl'd,
And rapid Rage, conumes the Britih World.
Blat him, O Heaven, in his mad Career,
And let thee Iles no more his Frenzy fear:
Curt—whom all Mankind abhor;
Fale to thy elf, but to thy Friend much more,
To him who did thy promis'd Pardon hope, (Coleman.
And with pretended Tranports kis the Rope;
Ore-whelm'd with Grief, and gaping out a Lie,
Deceiv'd, and unprepar'd, thou lett him die
With equal Gratitude and Treachery.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.l: AH Raleigh, when thou didt thy Breath reign
To trembling James, would I had quitted mine.
Cubs did't thou call them? Hadt thou een this Brood
Of Earls, Dukes, and Princes of the Blood;
No more of Scottih Race thou wouldt complain
Thee would be Bleings in this purious Reign.
Awake, arie from thy long blet Repoe;
Once more with me partake of Morlace Woes.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: What mighty Pow'r hath forc'd me from my ret?
Oh mighty Queen, why o untimely dret?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.l: Favour'd by Night, conceal'd in this Diguie,
Whilt the lewd Court in drunken Slumber lies,
I tole away, and never will return,
Till England knows who did her City burn;
Till Cavaliers hall Favourites be deem'd,
And Loyal Sufferers by the Court eteem'd,
Till Liegh and Galloway hall Bribes reject;
Thus Osburn's Golden Cheat I hall detect:
Till Atheit L—le hall leave this Land,
And Commons Votes hall Cut-Noe Guards disband;
Till Kate a happy Mother hall become,
Till Charles loves Parliaments, and James hates Roome.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.l: What fatal Crimes make you for ever fly
Your once loved Court and Martyrs Progeny?

lg.l: A Colony of French poes the Court;
Pimps, Priets, Buffoons in the Privy Chamber port;
Such limy Monters ne'r approacht a Throne
Since Pharaoh's Days, nor o defil'd a Crown.
In acred Ear Tyrannick Arts they croak,
Pervert his Mind, and good Intentions choak;
Tell him of Golden Indies, Fairy Lands,
Leviathan, and abolute Commands.
Thus Fairy-like the King they teal away,
And in his room a Changling Lewis lay.
How oft have I him to himelf retor'd,
In's left the Scale, in's right hand plac'd the Sword?
Taught him their ue, what dangers would enue,
To them who trive to eparate thee two?
The bloody Scotih Chronicle read o're,
Shew'd him how many Kings in purple gore
Were hurl'd to Hell by cruel Tyrant Lore.
The other day fam'd Spencer I did bring,
In lofty Notes Tudor's blet Race to ing;
How Spain's proud Powers her Virgin Arms controul'd,
And Gold'n Days in peaceful Order roul'd;
How like ripe Fruit he dropt from off her Throne,
Full of grey Hairs, good Deeds, and great Renown.
As the Jeean Hero did appeae

l.U: tormy Rage, and topt his black Dieae;

lg.l: So the learn'd Bard, with Artful Song uppret
The welling Paion of his canker'd Breat,
And in his Heart kind Influences hed
Of Country Lore by Truth and Jutice bred:
Then, to perform the Cure o full begun,
To him I hew'd this glorious etting Sun.
How by her Peoples Looks puru'd from far,
So mounted on a bright Celetial Car,
Out-hining Virgo, or the Julian Star.
Whilt in Truths Mirrour this good Scene he py'd,
Enter'd a Dame, bedeckt with potted Pride,
Fair Flower de Luce within an Azure Field,
Her left Hand bears the Ancient Gallick Shield,
By her uurp'd; her Right a bloody Sword,
Incrib'd Leviathan, our Soveraign Lord;
Her towry Front a fiery Meteor bears,
An Exhalation bred of Blood and Tears;
Around her Jove's lewd rav'nous Curs complain,
Pale Death, Lut, Tortures, fill her pompous Train:
She from the eaie King Truth's Mirrour took,
And on the Ground in piteful Fall it broke;
Then frowning thus, with proud Didain he broke.
Are thred-bare Virtues Ornaments for Kings?
Such poor Pedantick Toys teach Underlings.
Do Monarchs rie by Virtue or by Sword?
Who e're grew great by keeping of his Word?
Virtue's a faint Green-Sicknes to brave Souls,
Datards their Hearts, their active Heat controuls:
The Rival God, Monarchs of th' other World,
This mortal Poyon amongt Princes hold;
Fearing the mighty Projects of the great,
Shall drive them from their proud Coeletial Seat,
If not o're-aw'd: This new-found holy Cheat,
Thoe pious Frauds too light, t' innare the brave,
Are proper Acts of long-ear'd Rout t' inlave.
Bribe hungry Priets to deifie your Might,
To teach your Will's, your only Rule to Right;
And ound Damnation to all that dare deny't.
Thus Heaven deigns 'gaint Heaven you hould turn,
And make them fear thoe powers you once did corn.
When all the Gobling Interet of Mankind,
By Hirelings old to you hall be reign'd;
And by Impotures God and man betray'd,
The Church and State you afely may invade;
So boundles Law in its full power hines,
Whil't your tarv'd power in Legal Fetters pines.
Shake off thoe Baby Bands from your trong Arms,
Henceforth be deaf to your old Witches Charms;
Tat the delicious Sweets of Sovereign power,
'Tis Royal Game whole Kingdoms to deflower.
Three potles Virgins to your Bed I'le bring,
A Sacrifice to you their God and King:
As thee grow tale we'l harras human kind,
Rack Nature till new pleaures you hall find,
Strong as your Reign, and beauteous as your Mind.
When he had poke, a confus'd Murmour roe
Of French, Scotch, Irih, all my mortal Foes,
Some Englih too, O hame! diguis'd I py'd,
Led all by the wie Son-in-Law of Hyde;
With Fury drunk, like Baccanels they Roar,
Down wth that common Magna Charta Whore:
With joynt Conent on helples Me they flew,
And from my Charles to a bae Goal me drew;
My Reverend Age expos'd to Scorn and Shame,
To Prigs, Bawds, Whores, was made the publick Game.
Frequent Addrees to my Charles I end,
And my ad State did to his Care commend:
But his fair Soul transform'd by that French Dame,
Had lot a ene of Honour, Jutice, Fame.
Like a tame Spinter in's Seraigl he its,
Beieg'id by Whores, Buffoons and Batards Chits;
Lull'd in Security, rowling in Lut,
Reigns his Crown to Angel Cromwel's Trut.
Her Creature O—e, the Revenue teals,
Fale F—ch, Knave Ang—ery, miguide the Seals;
Mack-James the Irih Biggots does adore:
His French and Teague commands on ea and hore:
The Scotch Scalado of our Court two Iles,
Fale L—le with Adure all defiles.
Thus the States Right marr'd by this Hellih Court,
And no one left thee Furies to cat out:
Ah Vindex come, and purge the poion'd State;
Decend, Decend, e're the Cure's deperate.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.l: Once more great Queen thy Darling trive to ave,
Recue him again from candal and the Grave;
Preent to's Thoughts his long corn'd Parliament,
The Bais of his Throne and Government:
In his deaf Ears ound his dead Fathers Name,
Perhaps that Spell may his ill Soul reclaim;
Who knows what good Effects from thence may pring?
'Tis God-like Good to ave a falling King.

lg.l: As eaily learn'd Vertuoo's may
With the Dogs Blood his gentle Kind Convey
Into the Wolf, and make him Guardian turn,
To the bleating Flock, by him o lately torn;
If this Imperial Juice once taint his Blood,
'Tis by no potent Antidote withtood.
Tyrants, like Leprous Kings, for publick weal,
Should be immur'd, let the Contagion teal
Over the whole. Th' Elect of the Jeean Line,
To this firm Law their Scepter did reign.
To the erene Venetian State I'le go,
From her age Mouth fam'd Principles to know;
With her, the prudence of the ancients read,
To teach my people in their teps to tread;
By their great Pattern uch a State I'le frame,
Shall eternize a glorious lating Name.
Till then, my Raleigh teach our noble Youth,
To love Sobriety and holy Truth:
Watch and preide over their tender Age,
Let Court Corruption hould their Soul engage:
Tell them how Arts and Arms in thy young Days
Employ'd our Youth, not Taverns, Stews and Plays:
Tell them the generous Scorn their rie does ow
To Flattery, Pimping and a Gawdy Shew:
Teach them to corn the Corwells, P—s, Neils,
The Clevelands, Osborns, Berties, Lau—ails,
Poppea, Tegoline and Arteria's Name,
Who yield to thee in Lewdnes, Lut and Fame.
Make 'em admire the Talbots, Sidneys, Veres,
Drake, Cav'ndih, Blake, Men void of lavih Fears,
True Sons of Glory, Pillars of the State,
On whoe fam'd Deeds all Tongues and Writers wait;
When with bright Ardour their bright Souls do burn,
Back to my dearet Country I'le return.
Tarquin's jut Judge and Caear's equal Peers,
With them I'le bring, to dry my Peoples Tears.
Publicola with healing Hands hall pour
Balm in their Wounds, and hall their Life retore:
Greek Arts and Roman Arms in her conjoyn'd,
Shall England raie, relieve oppret Mankind.
As Jove's great Son th' infeted Globe did free
From noxious Monters, hell-bred Tyranny;
So hall my England in a Holy War,
In Triumph bear lain Tyrants from afar;
Her true Cruado hall at lat pull down
The Turkih Crecent and the Perian Sun.
Freed by my Labours, Fortunate Blet Ile,
The Earth hall ret, the Heaven hall on thee mile;
And this kind Secret for Reward hall give,
No Poyonous Serpent on the Earth hall live.
AS Citizens, that to their Conquerors yield,
Do at their own Charge their own Citadel build;
So Sir Robert advanced the King's Statue, a Token
Of a Broker defeated, and Lombard-treet broken.
Some thought it a mighty and gracious Deed,
Obliging the City with a King on a Steed;
When with honour he might from his Word have gone back,
Who that waits for a Calm, is abolv'd by a Wreck:
By all, it appears from the firt to the lat,
To be as Revenge and as Malice forecat,
Upon the Kings Birth Day to et up a Thing,
That hews him a Monkey, more like than a King.
When each one that paes, finds fault with the Hore,
Yet all do aure that the King is much wore:
And ome by the Likenes, Sir Robert upect,
That he did for the K—his own Statue erect.
To ee him o diguis'd, the Herb-women chide,
Who upon their Panniers more decently ride:
And o looe are his feet, that all men agree
Sir William Peak its more fater than he:
But a Market they ay doth fit the King well,
Who oft Parliaments buys, and Revenues doth ell:
And others, to make the Similitude hold,
Say his Majety himelf is oft bought and old.
Surely this Statue is more dangerous far,
Than all the Dutch Pictures that caued the War;
And what the Exchequer for that took on trut,
May henceforth be conficated for Reaons mot jut.
But Sir Robert, to take the Scandal away,
Doth the fault upon the Artificer lay;
And alledges the thing is none of his own;
For he counterfeits only in Gold, not in Stone.
But Sir Knight of the Vine, how came't in your thought,
That when to the Sc—Id your Liege you had brought,
With Canvas and Deals you ere ince do him cloud,
As if you had meant it his Coffin and Shroud?
Hath Blood him away, as his Crown he convey'd?
Or is he to Clayton's gone in Maquerade?
Or is he in his Cabal in his—et?
Or have you to the Compter remov'd him for Debt?
Methinks for the Equipage of this vile Scene,
That to change him into a Jack-Pudding you mean,
Or ele thus expoe him to Popular Flout,
As tho' we had as good have a King of a Clout.
Or do you his Errors out of Modety vail
With three hatter'd Planks, and the Rags of a Sail,
To expoe how his Navy was hatter'd and torn,
The day that he was retored and born?
If the Judges and Parliament do not him enrich,
They will carcely afford him a Rag to his Breech.
Sir Robert affirms they do him much wrong;
'Tis the Gravers Work to reform o long.
But alas, he will never arrive at his end;
For 'tis uch a King no Chizzel can mend:
But with all his faults pray give us our King,
As ever you hope December or Spring:
For though the whole World cannot hew uch another,
We had better have him than his P—'d Brother.

div.head: A Young Gentleman, deirous to be a Miniter of State, thus pretends to qualifie himelf.
div.l: TO make my elf for this Employment fit,
I'le learn as much as I can ever get
Of the Honourable G—y of R—Wit:
In Contancy and incere Loyalty,
I'le imitate the grateful Shaftsbury;
And that we may aume the Churches weal,
And all Diorder in Religion heal,
I will epoue Lord H—'s Zeal:
To pay Repect to Sacred Revelation,
To corn th' affected Wit of Prophanation,
And rout Impiety out of the Nation:
To uppres Vice and Scandal to prevent,
Buck—'s Life hall be my Precedent,
That living Modal of good Covernment.
To dive into the depth of Statemen's Craft,
To earch the Secrets of the ubtlet Heart,
And hide my own deigns with prudent Art:
To make each Man my Property become,
To frutrate all the Plots of France or Rome,
None can o well intruct as my Lord Moon;
For Moral Honety in Deed and Word,
Lord W—r Example will afford;
That, and his Courage too, are on Record.

div.head: To the King.
div.l: GReat Charles, who full of Mercy, wouldt command
In Peace and Pleaure this, his Native Land;
At lat take pity of this tottering Throne,
Shook by the Faults of others, not thine own.
Let not thy Life and Crown together end,
Detroy'd by a fale Brother and a Friend.
Oberve the danger that appears o near,
That all your Subjects do each minute fear:
One drop of Poion, or a Papit-Knife,
Ends all the Joy of England with thy Life.
Brothers, 'tis true, by Nature, hould be kind;
But a too zealous and ambitious Mind,
Brib'd with a Crown on Earth, and one above,
Harbours no Friendhip, Tendernes, or Love:
See in all Ages what Examples are
Of Monarchs murther'd by their impatient Heir.
Hard Fate of Princes, who will ne're believe
Till the Stroke's truck which they can ne're retrieve

lg.l: FOR Faults and Follies London's Doom hall fix,
And She mut ink in Flames in Sixty ix;
Fire-Balls hall fly, but few hall ee the Train,
As far as from White-hall to Pudding-Lane,
To burn the City, which again hall rie,
Beyond all hopes, apiring to the Skies,
Where Vengeance dwells. But there is one thing more
(Though its Walls tand) hall bring the City lower:
When Legilators hall their Trut betray,
Saving their own, hall give the ret away;
And thoe fale men by th' eaie People ent,
Give Taxes to the King by Parliament:
When bare-fac'd Villains hall not bluh to cheat,
And Chequer-Doors hall hut up Lumbard-treet:
When Players come to act the part of Queens,
Within the Curtains, and behind the Scenes:
When Sodomy hall be prime Min'ters Sport,
And Whoring hall be the leat Crime at Court:
When Boys hall take their Siters for their Mate,
And practice Incets between Seven and Eight:
When no man knows in whom to put his trut,
And e'en to rob the Chequer hall be jut;
When Declarations, Lie, and every Oath
Shall be in ue at Court but Faith and Troth;
When two good Kings hall be at Brentford Town,
And when in London there hall be not one;
When the eat's given to a talking Fool,
Whom wie men laugh at, and whom Women rule;
A Min'ter able only in his Tongue,
To make harh, empty peeches two hours long;
When an old Scotch Covenant hall be
The Champion for th' Englih Hierarchy;
When Bihops hall lay all Religion by,
And trive by Law t' etablih Tyranny;
When a lean Treaurer hall in one year
Make himelf fat, his King and People bare;
When th' Englih Prince hall Englih men depie,
And think French only Loyal, Irih Wie;
When Wooden Shoon hall be the Englih wear,
And Magna Charta hall no more appear;
Then th' Englih hall a greater Tyrant know
Than either Greek or Latin Story how;
Their Wives to's Lut expos'd, their Wealth to's Spoil,
VVith Groans to fill his Treaury they toil;
But like the Bellides mut igh in vain;
For that till fill'd flows out as fat again;
Then they with envious Eyes hall Belgium ee,
And wih in vain Venetian Liberty.
The Frogs too late, grown weary of their pain,
Shall pray to Jove to take him back again.
IT happen'd in the Twilight of the Day,
As England's Monarch in his Cloet lay,
And Chiffinch tep'd to fetch the Female Prey;
The bloody hape of Godfrey did appear,
And in ad Vocal ounds thee things declare:
"Behold, Great Sir, I from the Shades am ent,
"To hew thee Wounds that did your Fall prevent.
"My panting Ghot, as Envoy, comes to call,
"And warn you, let, like me, y' untimely fall;
"Who againt Law your Subjects Lives purue,
"By the ame rate may dare to murther you.
"I, for Religion, Laws, and Liberties,
"Am mangled thus, and made a Sacrifice.
"Think what befel Great Egypt's hardned King,
"Who corn'd the Profit of admonihing.
"Shake off your brandy lumbers; for my Words
"More Truth than all your cloe Cabal affords:
"A Court you have with Luxury oregrown,
"And all the Vices ere in Nature known;
"VVhere Pimps and Panders in their Coaches ride,
"And in Lampoons and Songs your Lut deride.
"Old Bawds and lighted VVhores, there tell, with hame,
"The dull Romance of your Lacivious Flame.
"Players and Scaramouches are your Joy;
"Priets and French Apes do all your Land annoy;
"Still o profue, you are inolvent grown,
"A Mighty Bankrupt on a Golden Throne.
"Your naueous Palate the wort Food doth crave;
"No wholom Viands can an entrance have:
"Each Night you lodge in that French Syren's Arms
"She trait betrays you with her wanton Charms;
"Works on your Heart, oftned with Love and Wine,
"And then betrays you to ome Philitine.
"Imperial Lut does o're your Scepter way;
"And though a Soveraign makes you to obey.
"Yet thoughts o tupid have your Soul poe'd,
"As if inchanted by ome Magick Priet.
"Next he who 'gaint the Senate's Vote did wed,
"Took defil'd H. and Heti to his Bed:
"Fiend in his Face, Apotle in his Name,
"Contriv'd to Wars to your eternal hame.
"He ancient Laws and Liberties defies;
"On tanding Guards and new raied Force relies:
"The Teagues he courts, and doth the French admire,
"And fain he would be mounted one tep higher.
"All this by you mut needs be plainly een,
"And yet he awes you with his darling Spleen.
"Th' unhappy Kingdom uffered much of Old,
"When Spencer and looe Gaveton controull'd;
"Yet they by jut Decrees were timely ent,
"To uffer a perpetual Banihment.
"But your bold States-men nothing can retrain,
"Their mot enormous Coures you maintain;
"Witnes that Man, who had for divers years
"Pay'd the Cubb-Commons, Penions and Arrears;
"Though your Exchequer was at his Command,
"Durt not before his jut Accuer tand,
"For Crimes and Treaons of o black a hue,
"None dare to prove his Advocate but you.
"Trut not in Prelates fale Divinity,
"Who wrong their Prince, and hame their Deity,
"Making their God o partial in their Caue,
"Exempting Kings alone from humane Laws.
"Thee lying Oracles they did infue
"Of old, and did your Martyr'd Sire abue.
"Their trong deluions did him o inthral,
"No Cautions would anticipate his Fall.
"Repent in time, and banih from your ight
"The Pimp, the Whore, Buffoon, Church-paraite;
"Let Innocence deck your remaining days,
"That After-ages may unfold your Praie.
"So may Hitorians in new Methods write,
"And draw a Curtain 'twixt your black and white.
The Ghot pake thus, groan'd thrice, and aid no more:
Straight in came Chiffinch hand in hand with Whore:
The King tho' much concern'd with Joy and Fear,
Starts from the Couch and bid the Dame draw near.

div.head: pon the King's Voyage to Chatham, to make Bulwarks againt the Dutch: And the Queen's micarriage thereupon.
div.l: WHen James our great Monarch, o Wie and Dicreet:
Was gone with three Barges, to face the Dutch Fleet
Our young Prince of Wales (by inheritance tout!)
Was coming to aid him and peep'd his Head out;
But eeing his Father without Ships or Men,
Commit the defence of us all to a Chain,
Taffee was frighted, and culk'd in again;
Nor thought, while the Dutch domineer'd on our Road
It was afe to come further, and venture abroad:
Not Walgrave, or th' Epitle of Seignieur le Duke,
Made Her Majety Sick, and her Royal Womb puke:
But the Dutch-men Pickeering at Dover and Harwich,
Gave the Miniters Agues, and the Queen a Micarriage;
And to ee the poor King tand in Ships of uch need,
Made the Catholicks quake, and Her Majety bleed;
And I wih the ad Accident don't poil the young Prince,
Take off all his Manhood, and make him a Wench:
But the Hero his Father no courage did lack;
Who was orry on uch a pretext to come back:
He mark'd out his ground, and mounted a Gun,
And 'tis thought without uch a pretence he had run;
For his Army and Navy were aid to increae,
As appears (when we have no occaion) in Peace:
Nay, if the Dutch come, we depie 'em o much,
Our Navy Incognito will leave 'em i'th' Lurch,
And (to their eternal Digrace) we are able
To beat 'em by way of a Pot and a Cable;
Why was this, Sir, left out of the Wie Declaration,
That flatter'd with Hopes of more Forces, the Nation?
'Twould have done us great good to have aid, you intended,
The trength of the Nation the CHAIN hould be mended;
Though we thank you, for Paing o kindly your Word,
(Which never was broke) that you'd Rule by the Sword;
This Promie we know you meant to fulfill;
And therefore you have reaon (by Gad) to tak't ill,
That the Bihops, the Bihops did throw out the Bill.

div.head: Three POEMS on the Death of the late Uurper Oliver Cromwell.
div.byline: Written by Mr. John Dryden, Mr. Sprat of Oxford, and Mr. Edm. Waller.

div.head: Heroick Stanza's, on the late urper Oliver Cromwell, written after his Funeral, by Mr. Dryden.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: AND now 'tis time; for their officious hat,
Who would before have born him to the Sky,
Like eager Romans e're all Rites were pat,
Did let to oon the acred Eagle fly.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Though our bet Notes are Treaon to his Fame,
Join'd with the loud applaue of publick Voice;
Since Heaven, what praie we offer to his Name,
Hath rendred too Authentick by its choice;

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Though in his praie no Arts can liberal be,
Since they whoe Mues have the highet flown,
Add not to his Immortal Memory;
But do an act of Friendhip to their own:

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Yet 'tis our duty, and our interet too,
Such Monuments as we can build, to raie,
Let all the World prevent what we hould do,
And claim a Title in him by their Praie.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: How hall I then begin, or where conclude,
To draw a Fame o truly Circular?
For in a round, what order can be hew'd,
Where all the parts o equal perfect are?

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: His Grandeur he deriv'd from Heaven alone,
For he was great ere Fortune made him o,
And Wars like Mits that rie againt the San,
Made him but greater eem, not greater grow.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: No borrow'd Bays his Temples did adorn,
But to our Crown he did freh Jewels bring;
Nor was his Vertue poion'd oon as born,
With the too early thoughts of being King.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: Fortune (that eaie Mitris to the young,
But to her ancient Servants coy and hard)
Him, at that age, her Favourites rank'd among,
When he her bet lov'd Pompey did dicard.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: He private, mark'd the Faults of others way,
And et as Sea-marks for himelf to hun;
Not like rah Monarchs, who their youth betray,
By Acts their Age too late would wih undone.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: And yet Dominion was not his deign,
We owe that bleing not to him but Heaven,
Which to fair acts unought rewards did join,
Rewards that les to him, than us were given.

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: Our former Chief like Sticklers of the War,
Firt ought t'inflame the parties, then to poie:
The quarrel lov'd, but did the caue abhor,
And did not trike to hurt, but make a noie.

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: War, our Conumption, was their gainful Trade;
He inward bled, whilt they prolong'd our pain;
He fought to end our fighting, and aay'd
To tanch the blood by breathing of the Vein.

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: Swift and reitles through the Land he pat,
Like that bold Greek, who did the Eat ubdue,
And made to Battels uch Heroick hate,
As if on Wings of Victory he flew.

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: He Fought ecure of Fortune as of Fame,
Still by new Maps the Iland might be hown,
Of Conquets which he trew'd where e're he came,
Thick as the Galaxy with Stars is own.

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: His Palms, though under weights they did not tand,
Still thriv'd, no Winter could his Laurels fade:
Heaven in his Portraict hew'd a Workman's hand,
And drew it perfect, yet without a hade.

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: Peace was the prize of all his toil and care,
Which War had banihd, and did now retore:
Bolognia's Walls thus mounted in the Air,
To eat themelves more urely than before:

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: Her afety, recued Ireland, to him owes,
And treacherous Scotland to no int'ret true,
Yet bles'd that Fate which did his Arms dipoe
Her Land to civilize, as to ubdue.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: Nor was he like thoe Stars which only hine,
When to pale Mariners, they Storms portend;
He had his calmer influences, and his Mien
Did Love and Majety together blend.

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: Tis true his Countenance did imprint an awe,
And naturally all Souls to his did bow,
As wands of Divination downward draw,
And point to beds where Sov'raign Gold doth grow.

lg.head: XX.
lg.l: When pat all offerings to Pheretrian Jove,
He Mars depoed, and Arms to Gowns made yield,
Succesful Councels did him oon approve,
As fit for cloe Intrigues, as open Field.

lg.head: XXI.
lg.l: To uppliant Holland he vouchaf'd a Peace,
Our once bold Rival in the Britih Main,
Now tamely glad her unjut claim to ceae,
And buy our Friendhip with her Idol, Gain.

lg.head: XXII.
lg.l: Fame of the aerted Sea through Europe blown,
Made France and Spain ambitious of his Love;
Each knew that ide mut conquer he would own,
And for him fiercely, as for Empire trove.

lg.head: XXIII.
lg.l: No ooner was the French-man's Caue imbrac'd,
Than the light Monieur, the grave Don outweigh'd;
His Fortune turn'd the Scale where it was cat;
Though Indian Mines where in the other laid.

lg.head: XXIV.
lg.l: When abent, yet we conquer'd in his Right;
For though that ome mean Artit's Skill were hown
In mingling Colours, or in placing Light;
Yet till the fair Deignment was his own.

lg.head: XXV.
lg.l: For from all Tempers he could Service draw;
The worth of each with its allay he knew;
And as the Confident of Nature aw
How he Complections did divide and brew.

lg.head: XXVI.
lg.l: Or he their ingle Vertues did urvey,
By intuition in his own large Breat,
Where all the rich Idea's of them lay,
That were the Rule and Meaure to the ret.

lg.head: XXVII.
lg.l: When uch Heroick Vertue, Heaven et out:
The Stars like Commons ullenly obey;
Becaue it drains them when it comes about;
And therefore is a Tax they eldom pay.

lg.head: XXVIII.
lg.l: From this high Spring, our Foreign Conquets flow,
Which yet more glorious Triumphs do portend;
Since their Commencement to his Arms they owe,
If prings as high as Fountains may acend.

lg.head: XXXIX.
lg.l: He made us Free-men of the Continent,
Whom Nature did like Captives treat before;
To Nobler preys the Englih Lion ent,
And taught him firt in Belgian Walks to roar.

lg.head: XXX.
lg.l: That old unquetion'd Pirate of the Land,
Proud Rome, with dread the Fate of Dunkirk heard;
And trembling wih'd behind more Alpes to tand,
Although an Alexander were her Guard.

lg.head: XXXI.
lg.l: By his Command, we boldly cros'd the Line,
And bravely fought where Southern Stars arie,
We trac'd the far-fetch'd Gold unto the Mine,
And that which brib'd our Fathers made our Prize.

lg.head: XXXII.
lg.l: Such was our Prince, yet own'd a Soul above
The highet Acts it could produce or how:
Thus poor Mechanick Arts in publick move,
Whilt the deep Secrets beyond Practice go.

lg.head: XXXIII.
lg.l: Nor died he when his ebbing Fame went les,
But when the freh Laurels courted him to live;
He eem'd but to prevent ome new Succes,
As if above what Triumphs Earth can give.

lg.head: XXXIV.
lg.l: His la tet Victories till thicket came,
As near the Center, Motion doth increae;
Till he pres'd down by his own weighty Name,
Did, like the Vetal, under poils deceae.

lg.head: XXXV.
lg.l: But firt the Ocean as a Tribute ent
That Giant Prince of all her wat'ry Herd;
And th' Ile, when her protecting Genius went,
Upon his Obequies loud ighs conferr'd.

lg.head: XXXVI.
lg.l: No civil broils have fince his Death aroe,
But Faction now by habit does obey;
And Wars have that repect for his Repoe,
As Winds for Halcyons when they breed at Sea.

lg.head: XXXVII.
lg.l: His Ahes in a peaceful Urn hall ret,
His Name a great Example tands to how,
How trangely high Endeavours may be blet,
Where Piety, and Valour jointly go.

div.head: To the Reverend Dr. Wilkins, Warden of Wadham Colledge in Oxford.

body.p:
SEeing you are pleaed to think fit that thee Papers hould come into the publick, which were at firt deign'd to live only in a Desk, or ome private Friends Hands; I humbly take the boldnes to commit them to the ecurity, which your Name and protection will give them, with the mot knowing part of the World. There are two things epecially, in which they tand in need of your defence: One is, That they fall o infinitely below the full and lofty Genius of that excellent Poet, who made this way of Writing Free of our Nation: The other, That they are o little proportioned and equal to the renown of that Prince, on whom they were written. Such great Actions and Lives, deerving rather to be the ubjects of the noblet Pens and most Divine Phanies, than of uch mall Beginners and week Eayers in Poetry as my elf. Againt thee dangerous prejudices, there remains no other hield, than the Univeral Eteem and Authority, which your Judgment and Approbation carries with it. The right you have to them, Sir, is not only on the account of the Relation you had to this great Peron, nor of the general favour which all arts receive from you; but more particularly by reaon of that Obligation and Zeal, with which I am bound to dedicate my elf to your ervice: For having been a long
time the Object of your Care and Indulgence towards the advantage of my Studies and Fortune, having been moulded (as it were) by your own Hands, and formed under your Government; not to intitle you to any thing which my meannes produces, would not only be Injutice, but Sacriledge: So that if there be any thing here tolerably aid, which deerves Pardon, it is yours Sir, as well as he, who is

closer.signed: Your mot Devoted and Obliged Servant.

div.head: To the happy memory of the late Uurper Oliver Cromwel. By Mr. Sprat of Oxon. Pindarick Odes.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: 'TIS true, great Name, thou art ecure
From the forgetfulnes and rage
Of Death, or Envy, or devouring Age;
Thou cant the Force and Teeth of Time endure:
Thy Fame like Men, the elder it doth grow,
Will of its elf turn whiter too,
Without what needles art can do;
Will live beyond thy breath, beyond thy Heare,
Though it were never heard or ung in Vere.
Without our help, thy Memory is afe;
They only want an Epitaph,
That does remain alone
Alive in an Incription,
Remembred only on the Bras, or Marble tone.
'Tis all in vain what we can do:
All our Roes and Perfumes
Will but officious folly hew,
And pious Nothings, to uch mighty Tombs.
All our Incene, Gums, and Balm,
Are but unneceary duties here:
The Poets may their Spices pare,
Their cotly numbers and their tuneful feet:
That need not be imbalm'd, which of it elf is weet.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: We know to praie thee is a dangerous proof
Of our Obedience and our Love:
For when the Sun and Fire meet,
Th' one's extinguih'd quite;
And yet the other never is more bright:
So they that write of thee, and join
Their feeble names with Thine,
Their weaker parks with thy illutrious light,
Will loe themelves in that ambitious thought;
And yet no Fame to thee from thence he brought.
We know, bles'd Spirit, thy mighty name
Wants no addition of anothers beam;
It's for our pens too high, and full of Theme:
The Mues are made great by thee, not thou by them.
Thy Fame's Eternal Lamp will live,
And in thy Sacred Urn urvive,
Without the food of Oil, which we can give.
'Tis true; but yet our duty calls our Songs,
Duty Commands our Tongues.
Though thou want not our praies, we
Are not excus'd for what we owe to thee;
For o Men from Religion are not freed.
But from the Altars clouds mut rie,
Though Heaven it elf doth nothing need,
And though the Gods don't want an earthly Sacrifice

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Great Life of wonders, whoe each year
Full of new Miracles did appear!
Whoe every Month might be
Alone a Chronicle, or a Hitory!
Others great Actions are
But thinly catter'd here and there;
At bet, but all one ingle Star;
But thine the Milky-way,
All one continued light of unditinguih'd day;
They throng'd o cloe, that nought ele could be een,
Scarce any common Sky did come between:
What hall I ay or where begin?
Thou may't in double hapes be hown,
Or in thy Arms, or in thy Gown;
Like Jove ometimes with Warlike Thunder, and
Sometimes with peaceful Scepter in his Hand,
Or in the Field, or on the Throne.
In what thy Head, or what thy Arm hath done,
All that thou didt was o refin'd,
So full of ubtance, and o trongly join'd,
So pure, o weighty Gold,
That the leat Grain of it
If fully pread and beat,
Would many Leaves and mighty Volumes hold

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Before thy Name was publih'd, and whilt yet
Thou only to thy elf wer't great,
Whilt yet thy happy bud
Was not quite een, or undertood,
It then ure igns of future greatnes hew'd:
Then thy Dometick worth
Did tell the World what it would be,
When it hould fit occaion ee,
When a full Spring hould call it forth:
As Bodies, in the dark and night,
Have the ame Colours, the ame red and white,
As in the open Day and Light,
The Sun doth only how
That they are bright, not make them o:
So whilt but private Walls did know
What we to uch a mighty Mind hould owe,
Then the ame Vertues did appear,
Though in a les and more contracted Sphere,
As full, though not as large as ince they were:
And like great Rivers, Fountains, though
At firt o deep thou didt not go;
Though then thine was not o inlarg'd a Flood;
Yet when 'twas little, 'twas as clear as good.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: 'Tis true thou wat not born unto a Crown,
Thy Scepter's not thy Father's, but thy own:
Thy purple was not made at once in hate,
And after many other Colours pat,
It took the deepet Princely Dye at lat.
Thou didt begin with leer Cares,
And private thoughts took up thy private Years:
Thoe Hands, which were ordain'd by Fates,
To change the World, and alter States,
Practis'd at firt that vat Deign
On meaner things with equal Mind.
That Soul, which hould o many Scepters way,
To whom o many Kingdoms hould obey:
Learned firt to rule in a Dometick way:
So Government it elf, began
From Family, and ingle Man,
Was by the mall Relations, firt,
Of Husband, and of Father Nurs'd,
And from thoe les beginnings pat,
To pread it elf o'er all the World at lat.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: But when thy Country, (then almot enthrall'd)
Thy Vertue, and thy Courage call'd;
When England did thy Arms intreat,
And 't had been Sin in thee not to be Great:
When every Stream, and every Flood,
Was a true Vein of Earth, and run with Blood;
When unus'd Arms, and unknown War
Fill'd every Place, and ever Ear;
When the great Storms, and dimal Night
Did all the Land affright;
'Twas time for thee, to bring forth all our Light.
Thou left't thy more delightful Peace,
Thy private Life, and better eae;
Then down thy Steel and Armour took,
Wihing that it till hung upon the Hook.
When Death had got a large Commiion out,
Throwing her Arrows, and her Stings about;
Then thou (as once the healing Serpent roe)
Wat lifted up, not for thy elf, but us.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Thy Country wounded was, and ick before
Thy Wars and Arms did her retore:
Thou knew't where the Dieae did lie,
And like the Cure of Sympathy,
Thy trong, and certain Remedy,
Unto the Weapon didt apply;
Thou didt not draw the Sword, and o
Away the Scabbard throw;
As if thy Country hou'd
Be the Inheritance of Mars and Blood;
But that when the great work was pun,
War in it elf hould be undone;
That Peace might Land again upon the hore,
Richer and better than before:
The Husbandmen no Steel hould know,
None but the ueful Iron of the Plow;
That Bays might creep on every Spear:
And though our Sky was overpread
With a detructive red;
'Twas but till thou our Sun didt in full Light appear.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: When Ajax died, the Purple Blood
That from his gaping Wound had flow'd,
Turn'd into Letters, every Leaf
Had on it wrote his Epitaph:
So from that Crimon Flood
Which thou, by fate of times, wert led
Unwillingly to hed,
Letters, and Learning roe, and were renewed:
Thou fought't not out of Envy, Hope, or Hate,
But to refine the Church and State,
And like the Romans, what e'er thou
In the Field of Mars didt mow,
Was, that a holy Iland thence might grow.
Thy Wars, as Rivers raied by a Shower,
With welcome Clouds do pour:
Though they at firt may eem,
To carry all away with an inraged Stream;
Yet did not happen that they might detroy,
Or the better parts annoy:
But all the Filth and Mud to cour,
And leave behind anothr lime,
To give a Birth to a more happy Power.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: In Fields unconquer'd, and o well
Thou did't in Battels and in Arms excel,
That teely Arms themelves, might be
Worn out in War as oon as thee.
Succes, o cloe upon thy Troops did wait,
As if thou firt had't conquer'd Fate;
As if uncertain Victory
Had been firt overcome by thee;
As if her Wings were clipp'd, and could not flee,
Whilt thou did't only erve,
Before thou had't what firt thou did't deerve.
Others by thee did great things do,
Triumph'd't thy elf, and made't them triumph too;
Though they above thee did appear,
As yet in a more large, and higher Sphere:
Thou, the great Sun gav't Light to every Star.
Thy elf an Army wert alone,
And mighty Troops contain'dt in one:
Thy only Sword did guard the Land,
Like that which flaming in the Angel's Hand,
From Men God's Garden did defend:
But yet thy Sword did more than his,
Not only guarded, but did make this Land a Paradiee.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: Thou fought't not to be high or great,
Not for a Scepter, or a Crown,
Or Ermyn, People, or the Throne:
But as the Vetal Heat
Thy Fire was kindled from above alone;
Religion putting on thy Shield,
Brought thee victorious to the Field.
Thy Arms like thoe, which ancient Heroes wore,
Were given by the God thou did't adore;
And all the Words thy Armies had,
Were on an heavenly Anvil made;
Not Int'ret, or any weak deire
Of Rule, or Empire did thy mind inpire;
Thy Valour like the holy Fire,
Which did before the Perian Armies go,
Liv'd in the Camp, and yet was acred too:
Thy mighty Sword anticipates,
What was reerv'd for Heaven and thoe bles'd Seats,
And makes the Church Triumphant here below.

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: Though Fortune did hang on thy Sword,
And did obey thy mighty Word;
Though Fortune for thy ide and thee,
Forgot her lov'd Uncontancy;
Amidt thy Arms and Trophies thou
Wert valiant and gentle too,
Wounded't thy elf, when thou did't kill thy Foe;
Like Steel, when it much Work has pat,
That which was rough does hine at lat:
Thy Arms by being oftner us'd did moother grow;
Nor did thy Battels make the proud or high;
Thy Conquet rais'd the State, not thee:
Thou overcam't thy elf in every Victory:
As when the Sun, in a directer Line,
Upon a polih'd golden Shield doth hine,
The Shield reflects unto the Sun again his Light:
So when the Heavens mil'd on thee in Fight,
When thy propitious God had lent
Succes, and Victory to thy Tent,
To Heav'n again the Victory was ent.

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: England till thou did't come,
Confin'd her Valour home;
Then our own Rocks did tand
Bounds to our Fame as well as Land,
And were to us as well,
As to our Enemies unpaable.
We were aham'd at what we read,
And bluh'd at what our Fathers did,
Becaue we came o far behind the Dead
The Britih Lion hung his main, and droop'd,
To Slavery and Burthen toop'd,
With a degenarate Sleep and Fear
Lay in his Den, and languih'd there;
At whoe leat Voice before,
A trembling eccho ran through every Shore,
And hook the World at every roar;
Thou his ubdued Courage didt retore,
Sharpen his Claws, and in his Eyes
Mad't the ame dreadful Lightning rie;
Mad't him again affright the Neighbouring Floods,
His mighty Thunder ound through all the Woods
Thou hat our Military Fame redeem'd,
Which was lot, or clouded eem'd:
Nay more, Heaven did by thee betow
On us, at once an Iron Age, and happy too.

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: Till thou command't, that Azure Chains of Waves,
Which Nature round about us ent,
Made us to every Pirate Slaves,
Was rather Burthen than an Ornament;
Thoe Fields of Sea, that wah'd our Shores,
Were plow'd, and reap'd by other Hands than ours.
To us, the liquid Mas,
Which doth about us run,
As it is to the Sun,
Only a Bed to leep on was:
And not, as now a powerful Throne,
To hake and way the World thereon.
Our Princes in their Hand a Globe did hew,
But not a perfect one,
Compos'd of Earth, and Water too.
But thy Commands the Floods obey'd,
Thou all the Wildernes of VVater way'd;
Thou did't but only wed the Sea,
Not make her equal, but a Slave to thee.
Neptune himelf did bear thy Yoke,
Stoop'd, and trembled at thy troke:
He that ruled all the Main,
Acknowledg'd thee his Soveraign.
And now the Conquer'd Sea, doth pay
More Tribute to thy Thames, than that unto the Sea.

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: Till now our Valour did our elves more hurt;
Our VVounds to other Nations were a port;
And as the Earth, our Land produc'd
Iron and Steel, which hould to tear our elves be us'd.
Our trength within it elf did break,
Like thundring Canons crack,
And kill'd thoe that were near,
While the Enemies ecur'd and untouch'd were.
But now our Trumpets thou hat made to ound,
Againt our Enemies Walls in Foreign Ground;
And yet no eccho back to us returning found.
England is now the happy peaceful Ile,
And all the World the while,
Is exerciing Arms and Wars,
With Foreign, or intetine Jars.
The Torch extinguih'd here, we lend to others Oil,
We give to all, yet know our elves no Fear;
We reach the Flame of Ruine, and of Death,
Where e're we pleae, our Swords to unheath,
Whilt we in calm, and temporate Regions breath;
Like to the Sun, whoe heat is hurl'd
Through every Corner of the World;
Whoe Flame through all the Air doth go;
And yet the Sun himelf, the while no Fire doth know.

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: Beides the Glories of thy Peace,
Are not in Number, nor in value les.
Thy Hand did cure, and cloe the Stars
Of our bloody Civil Wars;
Not only lanc'd; but heal'd the Wound,
Made us again as healthy, and as ound,
When now the Ship was well nigh lot,
After the Storm upon the Coat,
By its Mariners indanger'd mot;
When they their Ropes and helms had left,
When the Planks aunder cleft,
And Flouds came roaring in with mighty ound;
Thou a afe Land, and harbour for us found,
And aved't thoe that would themelves have drown'd:
A Work which none but Heaven and thee could do,
Thou made't us happy whe'r we would or no:
Thy Judgment, Mercy, Temperance o great,
As if thoe Vettues only in thy Mind had eat:
Thy Piety not only in the Field, but Peace,
When Heaven eemed to be wanted leat:
Thy Temples not like Janus open were,
Open in time of War,
When thou hadt greater caue of fear
Religion and the awe of Heaven poet
All places and all times alike thy breat.

lg.head: XVI:
lg.l: Nor didt thou only for thy age provide,
But for the years to come beide;
Our after-times, and late Poterity,
Shall pay unto thy Fame as much as we;
They too are made by thee:
When Fate did call thee to a higher Throne,
And when thy Mortal Work was done,
When Heaven did ay it, and thou mut be gone,
Thou him to bear thy burthen choe,
Who might (if any could) make us forget thy los:
Nor hadt thou him deign'd,
Had he not been
Not only to thy Blood, but Vertue kin;
Not only Heir unto thy Throne, but Mind,
'Tis he hall perfect all thy Cures,
And with as fine a thread weave out thy loom:
So one did bring the choen People from
Their Slavery and Fears,
Led them through their pathles road,
Guided himelf by God.
He brought them to the Borders; but a econd Hand
Did ettle, and ecure them in the promied Land.

div.head: pon the late Storm, and Death of the late urper Oliver Cromwel enuing the ame, By Mr. Waller.
div.l: WE mut reign; Heav'n his great Soul does claim,
In Storms as loud, as his Immortal Fame;
His dying Groans, his lat breath hakes our Ile,
And trees uncut fall for his Funeral Pile.
About his Palace their broad roots are tot
Into the Air: So Romulus was lot.
New Rome in uch a Tempet mit their King,
And from obeying-fell to Worhipping.
On Oeta's top thus Hercules lay dead,
With ruin'd Oaks and Pines about him pread;
The Poplar too, whoe bough he wont to wear
On his Victorious head, lay protrate there:
Thoe his lat Fury from the Mountain rent;
Our dying Hero, from the Continent,
Ravih'd whole Towns, and Forts from Spaniards reft,
As his lat Legacy to Britain left;
The Ocean which o long our hopes confin'd,
Could give no limits to his vater mind;
Our bounds enlargement, was his latet toil,
Nor hath he left us Prioners to our Ile:
Under the Tropick is our Language poke,
And part of Flanders hath receiv'd our Yoke.
From Civil broils, he did us diingage,
Found Nobler Objects for our Martial rage;
And with wie Conduct to his Country how'd,
Their ancient way of Conquering abroad:
Ungrateful then, if we no tears allow
To him, that gave us Peace and Empire too;
Princes that fear'd him, griev'd, concern'd to ee
No pitch of Glory from the Grave is free;
Nature her elf, took notice of his Death,
And ighing well'd the Sea with uch a breath,
That to remotet hores her Billows rowl'd,
Th' approaching Fate of her great Ruler told.
